persian.text: The needle makes clothes but stays naked. ~ Persian Saying
Treat your superior as a father, your equal as a brother, and your inferior as a son
It is nothing for one to know something unless another knows you know it
"That smells bad," said the cat about meat that it cannot reach.
A bad event had a good sequel.
A bad wound heals, but a bad word doesn’t.
A bee is always behind the flower.
A beggar will always be a beggar even if they give him the whole world as a gift.
A blind man who sees is better than a sighted man who is blind.
A broken hand works, but not a broken heart.
A broken sleeve holdeth the arm back.
A camel does not drink with a spoon.
A camel that wants fodder stretches out its neck.
A child is a bridge to heaven.
A coquettish woman is like a shadow — as you chase her she runs away, and if you run away, she chases after you.
A coquettish woman is like a shadow — as you chase her she runs away, and if you run away, she chases after you.
A crazy person enjoys meeting another one.
A dog by your side is better than a brother miles away.
A drop is ocean only when it is in the ocean.
A drop of rain makes no impression on a hard stone.
A drowning man is not bothered by rain.
A ewer and a hose do the same thing, but their real values show when they are pawned.
A flower is beautiful from all sides.
A fool and his money are soon parted.
A fool’s excuse is bigger than his mistake.
A friend is like a poem.
A gentle hand may lead even an elephant by a single hair.
A good appetite needs no sauce.
A good year is apparent from the spring.
A good year is evident in its Spring.
A hasty man does things twice
A hungry man dreams of sangak bread.
A hungry person dreams of sangak bread.
A lazy sheep thinks its wool heavy.
A leopard cannot change its spots. Putting lipstick on a pig doesn’t make it a lady.
A liar is forgetful.
A liar should have a good memory.
A man can pose as a wise when searching for wisdom, but if he believes to have find it, is a fool.
A man without a child is a king without sorrows.
A man without passion is no son of Adam.
A man’s servant can live for a hundred years; the slave of a woman dies in six months.
A mirror does not reflect a broken heart.
A mountain never meets a mountain, but a man meets a man.
A person is trying to benefit from being close to opposing parties.
A quality statement often gets no answer.
A renter becomes a comfortable dweller.
A rolling stone gathers no moss.
persian.description: Only a stone that is in the same place for a long time will have moss growing on it. A stone on the move will remain bare. The same is true with people.

persian.text: A sharp tongue will cut off its own head.
A single flower makes not Spring.
A single rose does not mean that it is spring.
A slap in the face now is better than promised candy later.
A sluggard claims the wisdom of forty viziers.
A snake can change its skin but not its disposition.
A stone thrown at the right time is better than a stone thrown at the wrong time.
A stone thrown at the right time is better than gold given at the wrong time.
A sword in the hands of a drunken slave is less dangerous than science in the hands of the immoral.
A sword in the hands of a drunken slave is less dangerous than science in the hands of the unscrupulous.
A tear at the right moment is better than a misplaced smile.
A thief is a king until he is caught.
A thief knows a thief as a wolf knows a wolf.
A timely tear is better than a misplaced smile.
A visitor comes with ten blessings, eats one, and leaves nine.
A wise enemy is better than a foolish friend.
A wise man can laugh at his jokes.
A wolf’s repentance died a long time ago.
Acquaintance without patience is like a candle with no light.
All fur coat and no knickers
All that glitters is not gold.
All that is round is not walnut.
All work is as seed sown; it grows and spreads, and sows itself anew.
Amongst the genus of Jasminum, a single jasmine does not stand out.
An alive person needs life.
An arrow can be pulled out of a wound, but a hurtful word stays forever in your heart.
An ass is the most pleasing to another ass.
An egg thief becomes a camel thief.
An event is so improbable that its occurrence is akin to cacophony sounding mellifluous.
An honest broker shares in people’s wealth.
An infidel believes of everybody being of his own faith.
An ungrateful son is a wart on his father’s nose – he leaves it, it’s ugly, he removes it, it hurts.
Appearances can be deceptive.
Applied when a person mentions the problems of another without seeing his own bigger problems.
Arabic is a language, Persian is a delicacy and Turkish is an art.
As long as the clouds dolt weep, the pasture cannot laugh.
As long as you are standing, give a hand to those who have fallen.
As soon as a man gets new trousers, he thinks about a new wife.
As the best wine makes the sharpest vinegar, the truest lover may turn into the worst enemy.
As the wise man looks for a bridge the fool crosses the river.
Asked for an eye-witness, the fox offered his tail.
Aspiration is not a defect for youngsters.
Bake the bread while the oven is hot.
Bam’s eggplant doesn’t have a defect.
Be a lion at home and a fox abroad.
Be careful. People could be listening.
Be in league with the headman; pillage the village.
Be it a bread given to the beggar, be it one taken from him.
Be kind to the debtor and he becomes the creditor.
Be not all sugar, or the world will swallow you up; be not all wormwood, or the world will spit you out.
Beggars can’t be choosers.
persian.description: If someone gives you free things or offers to help you do something, you can’t ask for a different color or choose the perfect time in your schedule. When you receive free help or goods, you should accept what you’re offered—you can’t be picky (a “chooser”) because you’re not paying!

persian.text: Being tricky (untruthful) won’t get you to your goal.
Better safe than sorry.
Between two cooks, the soup becomes either salty or bland.
Beware a rickety wall, a savage dog, and a quarrelsome person.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Blood cannot be washed out with blood.
Bravery without foresight is like a blind horse.
Bribery makes both parties happy.
Bugbear took it all.
Bugbear took that pacifier.
Buy cheap, buy a heap.
By a sweet tongue and kindness, you can drag an elephant with a hair.
Children are the bridge to heaven.
Claim to virginity, after seven moppets!
Closing the barn door after the horses get out.
Cloud, wind, moon, and sky are at work. And when you earn a piece of bread, do not eat it in ignorance.
Come what may.
Comfortable is he who doesn’t have a donkey — Doesn’t know of its straw and barley.
Comfortable is he who doesn’t have a donkey — He who doesn’t know of its straw and barley.
Contrarily, they call the Negro Camphor.
Courteous men learn courtesy from the discourteous.
Courtesy is cumbersome to them that ken it not.
Courtesy on just one side can never last long.
Courtesy on one side can never last long.
Credit is better than wealth.
Crooked load will not get to the destination.
Curiosity is the key to knowledge.
Death is a camel that lies down at every door.
Death is a camel that lies down at everyone’s door.
Debts are like women, once you have them you can’t get rid of them.
Did you see the camel? No you did not!
Do a good thing and throw it in the river. God will reward you in the desert.
Do little things now; and big things will come to you.
Do little things now; so shall big things come to thee by and by asking to be done.
Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?
Do men gather grapes of thorns?
Do not be critical of what has been given to you for free.
Do not choose for anyone what you do not choose for yourself.
Do not cut down the tree that gives you shade.
Do not let the cat watch over the bacon.
Do not use words that are too big for your mouth.
Do well the little things now; so shall great things come to thee by and by asking to be done.
Don’t just take love—experience it.
Don’t be afraid of he who raises a hue and cry; be afraid of he who holds his head down.
Don’t be afraid of he who’s loud and noisy, be afraid of he who’s head is down.
Don’t bite the hand that feeds you.
persian.description: This proverb warns against acting mean to those who provide for you or who do nice things for you. If you were to bite the hand that gave you food, that hand probably won’t come back to feed you again. Then what would you eat? So you should be kind and thankful to those who care for you.

persian.text: Don’t borrow from a baby-boomer, if you borrow, don’t spend it.
Don’t borrow from a parvenu; if you do, don’t spend it.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
persian.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

persian.text: Don’t despise pepper because it is so small; eat, and see how pungent it is.
Don’t have too many irons in the fire.
Don’t judge a book by its cover
persian.description: Things are not always what they seem. This proverb teaches you not to make judgments about other people because of how they look or dress. A book with a boring or plain cover could be amazing. The same is true with people. A person might look like an athlete or fool, but there is probably a lot more to them than clothes suggest.

persian.text: Don’t just take love, experience it.
Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth.
Don’t rock the boat. Don’t make waves.
Doubt is the key to knowledge.
Doubt makes the mountain which faith can move.
Doubtful the die, and dire the cast.
Draw not thy bow before thy arrow be fixed.
Drawn wells have sweetest water.
Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.
Easy come, easy go.
persian.description: Money, fame, love or anything that happens easily can be lost just as quickly. If you get a lot of money or suddenly become famous, you could lose that money or fame very quickly—since you didn’t work hard to earn it.

persian.text: Eat bread and leek for one year, eat bread and butter for a hundred years.
Eat drink and make merry, for tomorrow you might die
Eating and sleeping is my profession, God Almighty is my protection.
Either God, or date
Empty vessels make the most noise. Barking dogs seldom bite.
Epigrams might succeed where epics fail.
Epigrams succeed where epics fail.
Even a hair off the bear is serendipitous.
Even if she had seven blind daughters, she’d marry them off in an hour.
Every fault that a Sultan pleases can be a quality.
Every man goes down to his death bearing in his hands only that which he has given away.
Every man is the architect of his own fortune.
Every man is the king of his own beard.
Every man is the smith of his own fortune.
Every rock strikes the feet of the poor.
Every tear has a smile behind it.
Every time something turns out missing.
Every tree is known by its fruit.
Everyone thinks his own spit tastes good.
Excessive praise is like an insult.
Expect trust from a dog but not from a woman.
Experience is a comb which nature gives to men when they are bald.
Fear those who do not fear God.
Fine words butter no parsnips.
Fire is a good servant but a bad master.
First dig a well, then steal the minaret.
First goblet and then drunkenness.
First goblet is still full, but you are sodden (or drunk).
First prove your brotherhood, then claim inheritance.
Five fingers are brothers, not equals.
Flies will easily fly into the honey — their problem is how to get out.
Flies will never leave the shop of a sweetmaker.
For a single guest, the host can a slaughter a cow.
For an ant to have wings would be his undoing.
For crystal rain falls from black clouds.
For his master the dog is a lion.
Forgiveness hides a pleasure that you can’t get back from revenge.
Four walls make a man free.
Friendship with a fool may turn into the hug of a bear.
From afar he takes the heart, from nearby the gall-bladder.
From sudden desire of halim he fell in the pot.
From this column to that column may be a relief.
From truth to falsehood there’s a four-finger distance.
From you motion, from God blessing.
From you, action, from God, benediction.
Get along with the village headman, plunder the village.
Give him an inch and he’ll take a mile.
Give nine, save ten.
Giving advice to the ignorant is like the rain falling on muddy ground.
Go and wake up your luck.
Go as far as you can see, and when you get there you’ll see further.
Go further and fare worse.
Go slowly and come slowly so that the cat won’t gore you.
God gives to us according to the measure of our hearts.
God provides, but He needs a nudge.
Goes in one ear comes out the other.
Gold bears more gold.
Good deeds return to the house of their author.
Good grape becomes fox’s possession.
Good poets are like angels of Heaven.
Goods have value only to those who desire them.
Great boast, small roast.
Great needs grow from great possessions.
Great talkers are little doers.
Habits are first cobwebs, then cables.
Had the crow been a surgeon, it would have stitched its own rear.
He doesn’t see any water; otherwise, he is a skilled swimmer.
He doesn’t see water, otherwise he is a skilled swimmer.
He eats sheep-tail with the wold, and cries with the shepherd.
He escaped the thief, and fell in fortune-teller’s trap.
He gives a party with bath-water.
He gives from caliph’s bag.
He gives him roast meat and beats him with the spit.
He has dealt with so many scoundrels that he himself has become the chief rogue.
He has eaten so many snakes that he has become a viper.
He has fallen off the donkey, but has found a date.
He has lost the horse, but is looking for the horseshoe.
He is still alive because he cannot afford a funeral.
He is still wet behind the ears.
He keeps her/his face red with slaps.
He makes the water muddy to fish.
He never tells the truth.
He pushes it away with the hand, but pulls it forward with the foot.
He pushes it back with his hand and pulls it in with his feet.
He runs with the hare and hunst with the hound.
He takes from one ear, and lets it out from the other ear.
He that sows shall also reap.
he tried to pluck under her/his eyebrow, but blinded the eye.
He wants the God and the date both.
He wants to have his cake and eat it too.
He wants to have it both ways.
He wants to let it go and still have it.
He who doesn’t go to war roars like a lion.
He who eats alone is Satan’s brother.
He who has a clean account, what fear of calculation does he have?
He who has been bitten by a snake fears a piece of string.
He who has had his nose in the air bites the dust in the end.
He who has only one enemy, meets him everywhere.
He who is honest at finance, what fear of audit will he have?

He who knows not, and knows not that he knows not, is a fool, shun him; He who knows not, and knows that he knows not, is a child, teach him. He who knows, and knows not that he knows, is asleep, wake him. He who knows, and knows that he knows, is wise, follow him.
He who puts on lordly airs winds up hauling hay.
He who sits waiting for his neighbor will go to bed hungry.
He who want a rose must respect the thorn.
He who wants content can’t find an easy chair.
He who wants the rose must respect the thorn.
He whose heart is aroused by love will never die.
He would even hang himself, provided that the rope is free.
He wouldn’t sleep where there is running water.
He, who has only one enemy, meets him everywhere.
He/she who blows into fire will have sparkles in his/her eyes.
Heaven is at the feet of mothers.
Hey sloth, don’t go into the shade, the shade would eventually come to you.
His mouth still smells of his mother’s milk.
His options are so limited that he has to settle for the worst pinchbeck.
History is a mirror of the past, and a lesson for the present.
Hitch a horse and an ass to the same post; if they don’t smell the same, they’ll behave the same.
Human beings need meaningful lives.
I attempted to be benevolent, but I got burnt.
I can only get better if I have good friends.
I cried because I had no shoes until I met a man who had no feet.
I eat what others have planted and I plant what others want to eat.
I gave so much advice that hair grew on my tongue.
I have no right to rejoice at the death of my enemy when I do not have eternal life myself.
I know entirely what kind of person you are.
I murmured because I had no shoes, until I met a man who had no feet.
I poured our own flour and hung our hair-sieve.
I took care of my own business.
I took the abandoned boy to be my son, but he became my husband.
I tried to do charity, I burned.
I used to complain because I had no shoes until I met a man who had no feet.
I used to complain because I had no shoes until I met a man who was dead.
I used to feel sorry for myself because I had no shoes until I met a man who was dead.
I was trying to help out, but I got in trouble myself.
I wept because I had no shoes, until I saw a man who had no feet.
I would have been for seven years.
If a fool borrows a book cut off his hand; but cut off both hands of the fool who brings it back.
If a man would live in peace, he should be blind, deaf, and dumb.
If Akbar doesn’t give, Akbar’s God gives.
If Ali is the camel-driver, he knows where to rest his camel.
If children’s prayer had any effect, there wouldn’t be a single teacher alive.
If everybody said bread and cheese, you put your head down and die.
If everyone said bread and cheese, you put your head down and desist.
If fortune turns against you, even jelly breaks your tooth.
If God wills, even males become fertile.
If he hadn’t seen his father, he would have claimed kingship.
If he has seven blind daughters, he will marry them in an hour.
If he hasn’t seen her/his father, he would claim to be a king.
If he says yogurt is white, I’ll say it’s black.
If he was any good, his name would be Kheirollah.
If he were a do-gooder, they’d call him Saint Do-Gooder.
If I haven’t eaten wheat-bread, I’ve seen it in people’s hands.
If it doesn’t have water for me, instead it has bread for you.
If my aunt had a beard, this man would be my uncle.
If one has to jump a stream and knows how wide it is, he will not jump. If he does not know how wide it is, he will jump, and six times out of ten he will make it.
If regret was a horn, one’s horn would reach the sky.
If regret was a horn, the fellow’s horn would reach the sky.
If something is needed at home, its donation is wrong
If the beginning is good, the end must be perfect.
If the lantern is needed at home, donating it to the mosque is haram (forbidden).
If the Lor doesn’t go to bazaar, everything will rot.
If the Sultan demands five eggs, let his soldiers roast a thousand chickens.
If the teacher be corrupt, the world will be corrupt.
If there are two cooks in one house, the soup is either too salty or too cold.
If they had planted "if," a tree would have grown in its place.
If we haven’t eaten wheat bread, we’ve seen it in people’s hands.
If wishes were horses, beggars would ride.
If you are a surgeon, set your own bones.
If you be a cock, crow; if a hen, lay eggs.
If you can give me no ointment for my wound, can you help me by not rubbing salt in?
If you do not like your image in the mirror, do not break the mirror. Break yours.
If you don’t crack the shell, you can’t eat the nut.
If you enter the city of the blind, cover your eyes.
If you exercise patience, you may make a sweet-meat out of the sour grape.
If you fall into a pit, Providence is under no obligation to come and look for you.
If you go on foot, you’ll wear out your shoes; if you go on head, you’ll wear out your hat.
If you know how to lullaby, why can’t you put yourself to sleep?
If you know lullaby, why can’t you sleep?
If you really have to sin, then choose a sin that you enjoy.
If you talk Ali to him, don’t mention Omar.
If you tell the truth too early, you are laughed at – too late and you are stoned.
If you walk with your feet your shoe will get worn, if you walk with your head, your hat.
If you work hard and live uncomfortably today, it’ll pay off in the future.
If you’re a reed-player, why did your father die of typhoid fever?
If you’re a shoveler, shovel your garden first.
In at one ear and out at the other.
In one ear, out the other.
In shaping one’s own fortune one should not rely on the help of others, as they are also concerned mainly about their own matters.
In the ants’ house the dew is a flood.
In the hotel of decisions the guests sleep well.
In the hour of adversity be not without hope For crystal rain falls from black clouds.
In the hour of adversity be not without hope.
In the hour of adversity do not give up hope for crystal rainfalls from black clouds.
In this world generous people have no money and those with money are not generous.
In winter a fire is better than a muscat blossom.
In your neighbors’ soup there is always one fatty morsel.
Injustice all around is justice!
It is a real compliment that comes from an enemy.
It is a wise man who can laugh at his own jokes.
It is better to be careful and to not risk making a big mistake.
It is better to be in chains with friends, than to be in a garden with strangers.
It is better to die in honor than to live in disgrace.
It is not from the love of God that the cat catches mice.
It is nothing for one to know something unless another knows you know it.
It is so unlikely to obtain anything from this person that even a smidgen is a win.
It is the mountains that do not move to help one another; but one man surely comes to the help of another.
It is the same to him who wears a shoe, as if the whole earth were covered with leather.
It is too late for you, let God give your children some intelligence.
It is too late for you, let God give your children some intelligence.
It seems like folly to give comfits to a cow – It can be fun anyway.
It takes ten pounds of common sense to carry one pound of learning.
It takes two days to learn everything about a man; to know animals you will need more time.
It’s better to flee and stay alive than to die and become a hero.
It’s better to fly and stay alive than to die a hero.
It’s from us that is on us.
It’s from us, what’s upon us.
It’s no use throwing good money after bad.
It’s not possible to go to sky by a ladder.
I’ve seen your top, I’ve seen your bottom also.
Keep your own counsel. Watch your back.
Kettledrum’s sound is nice when heard from afar.
Laugh and the world laughs with you.
Learn good manners from those who don’t have them.
Left from there, driven from here.
Let the manager manage.
Let the person in responsibility take care of the matter, as is the most able.
Life is like perpetual drunkenness, the pleasure passes but the headache remains.
Like a cow with a blaze.
Like fault, like punishment.
Listening to good advice is the way to wealth.
Little by little the cotton thread becomes a turban.
Little by little the wool becomes a carpet.
Look at the colander telling the pierced serving spoon, "You have three holes."
Look at the strainer that tells the skimmer: You have three holes.
Look in the sky to find the moon, not in the pond.
Luck is infatuated with the efficient.
Lucky are those who don’t have too many responsibilities.
Lying in the gutter, looking at the stars.
Make bread while the oven is hot.
Many a little makes a Mickle.
Marriage is an uncut watermelon.
Maturity comes from impressions for a long time.
Maturity comes from wisdom, not in the passing of years.
May God strike the rich man blind by his own gold.
Might as well be hanged for a sheep as a lamb. In for a penny, in for a pound.
Mo’ Money, Mo’ Problems.
Mountains don’t meet, but people do.
Much coin, much care.
My good deed was blamed or punished.
Necessity can change a lion into a fox.
Necessity turns lion into fox.
Never open a door that you can’t lock again.
No benefit has come from this individual.
No good comes of this person.
No good deed goes unpunished.
No lamp burns till morning.
Nobody sees a miracle from this shrine.
Not everyone who sings a lullaby stays awake.
Nothing is cheap for no reason.
Nothing is disturbed. No waves are made.
Of everything else the newest; of friends, the oldest.
Often the best way of giving oneself what one lacks is to take from oneself what one has.
Oh God: Three mishaps at the same time; a limping donkey, an ugly wife, and a creditor.
Oh peach, get into (my) throat.
Once a friend, always a friend.
Once I had the strength but no wisdom; now I have the wisdom but no strength.
One crow and forty crows.
One cuts and one sews.
One doesn’t pay attention to the given advice.
One finds money on Wednesday and one loses it.
One finger cannot lift a pebble.
One full stomach is better than hundred half-full stomachs.
One good father can do more than 100 schoolmasters.
One hurts you in a way you don’t register it.
One idiot throws a stone in the well, and it takes a hundred wise men to (try to) get it out.
One is very skillful.
One pound of learning could require an army of common sense to apply it.
One pound of learning might have required many thousand persons of common sense to acquire it.
One pound of learning requires ten pounds of common sense to apply it.
One scabby goat infects the flock.
One sin is too much, a hundred prayers are not enough.
One sip of wine is an antidote against death, cupfuls poison life.
One spark is enough to burn a hundred worlds.
One who is poor at finance pays twice.
One who’s been bitten by a snake is afraid of a black-and-white rope.
One who’s innocent is not afraid of investigation.
One’s children are almond hulls; one’s grandchildren are almond nuts.
One’s very regretful.
Only a heart can find the way to another heart.
Oosta Alam, take this one into account.
Our means are exiguous. (We continue to live, because we couldn’t afford the funeral cost, if we were to die.)
Our real grave is not in the ground but in men’s hearts.
Out of desperation, he calls donkey dame.
Out of extreme desire for achieving something, he got in trouble.
Out of the frying pan into the fire.
Play, play, with the beard of the father also play?
Pot calling the kettle black.
Poured clear water on hither hands.
Practice makes perfect.
persian.description: It would be amazing if the first time you picked up a guitar you could play it like a rock star. Or if the first time you got in a car, you could drive like a professional. Or if you could speak English perfectly after one lesson. Everything is difficult when you are a beginner. But if you stick with it, if you keep practicing, you can master anything.

persian.text: Practice what you preach.
persian.description: If you say that everyone needs to arrive on time, make sure that you also arrive on time.

persian.text: Praise a fair day at night.
Pride comes before a fall
Putting the cart before the horse.
Putting the cart before the horse.
Raise the one you’ve delivered.
Raise what you’ve given birth to.
Seek knowledge from the cradle to the grave.
Seek truth in meditation, not in moldy books. Look in the sky to find the moon, not in the pond.
Seven sets of ewers and washbowls, but no dinner or lunch.
Seven sets of ewers, but no dinner nor lunch.
Share and share alike.
She doles out of Caliph’s purse.
She has become hale. Her appearance has improved.
She is a mother to everyone, but a stepmother to us.
She is in the pink.
Silence betokens consent.
Silence is the sign of agreement.
So down-and-out, so high-and-mighty!
So many donkeys around, yet we have to hoof it.
Solved riddles look easy.
Some good poets are like angels of Heaven.
Someone is being generous at someone else’s expense.
Sometimes the body becomes healthy by being very sick.
Speak in the frame of reference of your audience.
Spectators see better than actors.
Spilled water cannot be gathered again.
Spring doesn’t come with just a single flower.
Spring won’t come from one flower.
Stand so much until grass grows under your foot.
Step by step one ascends the stairs.
Stretch your foot to the length of your blanket.
Take care lest your tongue should cut off your head.
Take from the hungry, give it to the full/satisfied.
Take it from the famished and give it to the nourished.
Take to your aunt what you’ve brought to me.
Taking the first step with the good thought, the second with the good word, and the third with the good deed, I enter paradise.
Taste it first before you say it’s saltless.
Tell a lazy man to do something. Listen to philosophy!
Tell me who your friends are, and I will tell you who you are!
That smells bad, said the cat about meat that it cannot reach.
The arrow that has left the bow never returns.
The best memory is that which forgets nothing, but injuries. Write kindness in marble and write injuries in the dust.
The best mode of instruction is to practise what we preach.
The best of friends must part.
The best of men are but men at best.
The big drum only sounds well from a distance.
The bigger a man’s head, the worse his headache.
The blind man is laughing at the bald head.
The branch that bears the most fruit bends itself thankfully towards the ground.
The bride who wears four petticoats has a lot to hide.
The cripple will always find a stone to kick.
The devil looks after his own.
The diamond fallen into the dunghill is not the less precious for it.
The doctor must heal his own bald head.
The dog is a lion in his own house.
The drowning man is not troubled by rain.
The earth is a host who kills his guests.
The elephant dreams of one thing, and the elephant driver dreams of another.
The ewer is cheaper than its solder.
The eyes can do a thousand things that the fingers can’t.
The fireside is the tulip bed of a winter day.
The fool’s excuse is bigger than the mistake he made.
The fox uses his tale as a witness.
The guard’s sleep is the lamplight of the thief.
The halfwit spoke, and the brainless believed.
The hand that gives is also the one that receives.
The horse is Turkmen, it eats from both the nose-bag and the manger.
The issue is muddled at the core.
The joy of finding something is often worth more than what is found.
The lack of gold only a headache.
The larger a man’s roof, the more snow it collects.
The leek resembles its seed and little Hassan takes after his father.
The legs of those who require proofs of God’s existence are made of wood.
The loveliest of faces are to be seen by moonlight, when one sees half with the eye and half with the fancy.
The lover who gives you her body but not her heart is generous with thornless roses.
The main thing is to be pretty and fair; bald spots are covered by the hair.
The mediator in a fight gets all the blows.
The monkey could not dance and blamed it on the floor as being crooked.
The mud that you throw will fall on your own head.
The needle makes clothes but stays naked.
The neighbor’s hen is a goose to a neighbor.
The night hides a world, but reveals a universe.
The ostrich was asked to carry a load, it said. I’m a bird. It was asked to fly, it said, I’m a camel.
The person is so destitute that his fortune will not change with a penny given or taken.
The person who tells the truth is always at ease.
The person who wants a rose must respect the thorn.
The pitcher is cheaper than its solder.
the place is wet and the child is missing.
The pleasure of finding something is worth more than what you find.
The pot calling the kettle black.
The public improves the speaker’s speech.
The reticent can be more dangerous than the boisterous.
The rich are subjugated by their greed for more riches.
The rich get richer, the poor get poorer.
The richer they are, the needier they are.
The shoemaker’s shoes have no heels.
The sky is of the same color wherever you go.
The sky is the same color wherever you go.
The solution is under our nose, yet we’re searching far and wide for it.
The strictness of the teacher is better to bear than the prejudice of the father.
The tears of the roasting meat kindle the fire even more.
The tongue of men is the whip of God.
The virtuous will be praised but not envied.
The walls have mice, the mice have ears.
The water doesn’t move.
The water has passed his head.
The way a house is decorated will tell much about its owner.
The wise man sits on the hole in his carpet.
The wise man who does not put his knowledge into practice is like a bee that gives no honey.
The world is a rose: smell it and pass it on to your friends.
The world is like an old building on the banks of a stream – it carries away piece by piece; in vain you stop it with a handful of earth.
There are four things every person has more of than they know . . .
There are four things every person has more of than they know; sins, debt, years, and foes.
There are four things in this life of which we have more than we think: faults, debts, years and enemies.
There are three kinds of enemy: the enemy himself, the friends of your enemy, and the enemies of your friends.
There are three things that have to be done quickly: burying the dead, opening the door for a stranger, and fixing your daughter’s wedding.
There is much hope in hopelessness; for at the end of the dark night, there is light.
There is no need for fish in an empty pond.
There is water in the jug, and we’re going around thirsty.
There’s not a single straight intestine in his belly.
These words won’t become a loose skirt for Fati.
They asked the mule who its father was and it said its uncle was a stallion.
They coordinate.
They don’t count the teeth of a gift horse.
They told the cat its stool was a cure-all, it strewed soil on it.
Thick body, weak soul.
Thinking is the essence of wisdom.
Thinking well is wise; planning well, wiser; but doing well is the wisest and best of all.
This caravan is lame until doomsday.
This is not Kashan where the heap comes with the coolies.
This person is perfectly suited for the job.
This prankster doesn’t stop short of any tricks.
This problem is not going to be solved.
This time the situation is completely different.
Those who are richer, are needier.
Those with meager means dream of riches.
Three things must be shunned: a broken wall, a ferocious dog, and a shrew.
‘Tis the same to him who wears a shoe, as if the whole earth were covered with leather
To the ant, a few drops of dew are a flood.
To the ant, a few drops of dew is a flood.
Too many cooks spoil the broth.
persian.description: Or as it’s more commonly said, “Too many cooks in the kitchen.” This is a well known experience—a lot people all trying to work in a kitchen around a small table or stovetop will make a mess and ruin the food. This proverb talks about the trouble of too many people trying to do the same thing at once.

persian.text: Too many decision-makers may doom the outcome.
Travel the highway, though it be roundabout – where shortcuts are dangerous.
Treat your superior as a father, your equal as a brother, and your inferior as a son.
Trust in God — but tie your camel tight.
Two midwives, and the baby’s head will be crooked.
Uneaten soup and burned mouth.
Upon arriving in paradise the wealthy man finds only a pot of oil to which he will be boiled until the flabby flesh falls from his stingy bones.
Use your enemy’s hand to catch a snake.
Usually said to the mother of a difficult child.
Walls have ears.
Walls have mice and mice have ears.
Water does not trickle out of his hand.
Water has leaked under her/his skin.
Water has seeped under her skin.
Water is in the jug, yet we’re wandering around with parched lips.
Water is muddy at the fountainhead.
Water is past his head.
Water long stagnant becomes putrid.
We are all unique.
We are not in charge of our own destiny.
We come into this world crying while all around us are smiling. May we so live that we go out of this world smiling while everybody around us is weeping.
We might’ve fallen from the horse, but not from the honor.
We might’ve had some misfortunes, but that doesn’t lower our class or diminish our patriciate.
We sifted our flour and hung up our sifter.
We’re alive from lack of a shroud.
We’re responsible for our own misfortune.
What can the enemy do when the friend is cordial.
What fear has he whose account is clean?
What goes around, comes around.
What I wished for happened not — What God willed happened to a dot.
What is brought by the wind will be carried away by the wind.
What my heart wanted didn’t happen — What God wanted, that happened.
What percolates out of the jug is what’s inside it.
What the thief stole has always been called expensive.
What you give away you keep.
What you hear about something may not be equivalent to its qualities.
What you’ve brought for me, take for your aunt.
Whatever I disliked, happened to me.
Whatever is in the heart will come up to the tongue.
Whatever you eat will rot, whatever you give will blossom into a rose.
When a cat wants to eat her kittens, she says they look like mice.
When a lion is old, he becomes the plaything of jackals.
When a stone hits glass, the glass breaks.
When a stone hits glass, the glass breaks. When glass hits a stone, the glass breaks.
When fate strikes physicians are useless.
When fortune turns against you, even jelly breaks your teeth.
When glass hits a stone, the glass breaks.
When I am dead the world can be an ocean or a dried up ditch.
When its time has arrived, the prey becomes the hunter.
When its time has come, the prey goes to the hunter.
When one is really thirsty, one thousand pearls are not what is craved for at all.
When the cat and the mouse agree, the grocer is ruined.
When the cat and the mouse agree, the store manager is broke.
When the snake is old, the frog will tease him.
When the tide of misfortune moves over you, even jelly will break your teeth.
When the water goes uphill, the frog sings AbuAta.
When there are two cooks, the soup becomes either salty or saltless.
When there are two cooks, the soup will be either too salty or tasteless.
When there’s fire, dry and wet burn together.
When water remains in one place, it spoils.
When water stays at one place, it rots.
When you lie down with dogs, you get up with fleas.
When you throw an apple up, it turns a thousand times before it come down.
Whenever you catch the fish it is fresh.
Where is the person who has not soiled his garments?
Where the camel is sold for a cent, the ass is worthless.
Where there is bear, there is fear.
Where there’s a beauty, there’s a beast also.
Where there’s smoke, there’s fire.
Whether you were gold or satin, you’re the same acanthus-seller.
While yearning for excess we lose the necessities.
While you were chirping with vernal giddiness, didn’t you think of brumal harshness?
Who does not beat his own child will later beat his own breast.
Who has ever seen tomorrow?
Who has not had a taste longs to do so, but for whom has tasted then the longing is a hundred times more.
Who is in fault suspects everybody.
Who sows barley cannot reap wheat.
Whoever can walk on water is probably made of straw.
Whoever challenges Ali will be doomed.
Whoever has no children has no light in his eyes.
Why don’t you follow your own advice?
Why would a pool that doesn’t have water need so many frogs?
Why would a pool with no water need so many frogs?
Why you asking an idiot?
With a sweet tongue and kindness, you can drag an elephant by a hair.
With a sweet tongue of kindness, you can drag an elephant by a hair.
With one ear he hears, and with the other he dismisses.
With this beard you want to go to Tajrish?
With time and art the leaf of a mulberry-tree becomes satin.
Woe is he who claims to have found happiness.
Woe to being a housewife/househusband, you buy one thing, you don’t have two others.
Woe to home-makers; you buy one thing, you don’t have two others.
Woe to Leili’s doogh (yogurt drink with water), the yogurt was too little and the water too much.
Woe to Leili’s doogh, the yogurt was too little and the water too much.
Woe to Leili’s doogh, the yogurt was too little and the water too much.
Women are just like cats — they always land on their feet.
Women are just like cats, they always land on their feet.
Work is twice done by the man in a hurry.
Year after year we long for (what we left behind) the previous year.
You aside, may God give your children some intelligence.
You ask the donkey when’s Wednesday?
You became full by eating not by licking.
You became full by eating, it won’t happen by licking.
You can close the city gates but not the mouths of men.
You can close the city gates, but you can’t close the people’s mouths.
You can stay here until the cows come home.
You can wait as much as you want, but it’s useless.
You can’t pick up two watermelons with one hand.
You can’t please everyone.
You can’t push on a rope.
You cannot applaud with one hand.
You cannot hang everything on one nail.
You cannot have everything at the same time.
You cannot have your cake and eat it too.
persian.description: If you eat your cake, you won’t have it anymore, will you? So you can’t do both. This proverb is about having two opposite desires, and how it’s impossible to get both. Its meaning is similar to the proverb, “You can’t have the best of both worlds.”

persian.text: You cannot milk a bull.
You can’t escape death and guests.
You can’t have your cake and eat it too.
persian.description: If you eat your cake, you won’t have it anymore, will you? So you can’t do both. This proverb is about having two opposite desires, and how it’s impossible to get both. Its meaning is similar to the proverb, “You can’t have the best of both worlds.”

persian.text: You can’t pick up two melons with one hand.
You can’t pick up two watermelons with one hand.
You can’t please everyone.
You can’t polish a turd.
You can’t push on a rope.
You can’t put an old head on young shoulders.
You can’t put new wine in old bottles.
You can’t squeeze blood from a rock.
You can’t take blood from a stone.
You don’t put a wooden pot on the fire twice.
You name it, this imp has done it.
You needed this like you needed a hole in the head.
You only appreciate your father the day you become a father yourself.
You see nothing, you hear nothing.
You should grease his palm.
You toss charity in the Tigris, and God shall return it in the desert.
Your appearance is not appropriate for the occasion.
You’ve grazed so much, where’s your tail-fat?
You’ve grazed so much; where’s your tail fat?
You’ve spent so much money on yourself; what good are you?
A fight in the beginning is better than peace in the end.
persian.category: go over the details before you agree to something.

persian.text: A mountain won’t catch up to a mountain, but a person will catch up to a person.
persian.category: be nice to people on your way up because you might meet them on your way down.

persian.text: Bake the bread while the oven is hot.
persian.category: do it while the opportunity is still there.

persian.text: Came out of the pothole, fell into the well.
persian.category: you may get out of one problem but then find yourself facing a bigger problem.

persian.text: Clothes after the New Year are good for the top of the minaret.
persian.category: a reference to being too late to do something.

persian.text: Coming back with arms longer than legs.
Don’t pick up two watermelons with one hand.
persian.category: don’t do too many things at the same time.

persian.text: Don’t stretch your legs beyond your quilt.
persian.category: know your limits and adapt to the situation.

persian.text: Door, I’m speaking to you. Wall, you listen.
Fallen from the elephant’s nose.
persian.category: said about a person who acts like a snob.

persian.text: First dig a well, then steal the minaret.
Gone to the judge alone, and is back happy.
persian.category: there are two sides to every story.

persian.text: He pulls a snake out of the nest with his tongue.
persian.category: about being diplomatic. a smooth talker.

persian.text: He who leaves the eye will leave the heart.
persian.description: if people don’t see you, they’ll forget you.]
persian.category: if people don’t see you, they’ll forget you.]

persian.text: Heaven is under the mother’s foot.
persian.category: if you respect your mother, you’ll go to heaven, that’s how high a mother’s place is.

persian.text: I haven’t come from behind the mountains.
If you don’t want to be found out, take the appearance of the people around you.
persian.description: When you are a visitor somewhere away from home, you should act like everyone else. It is polite to do so, and could keep you from getting into trouble. This proverb is from the ancient days of the Roman Empire when the capital city had visitors from all over the world. Cultures were very different between cities in those times. But while in Rome, one would behave like a Roman, no matter where you came from.
persian.category: when in rome, do as the romans do.

persian.text: If you see behind your ear.
persian.category: a reference to something that will never happen.

persian.text: Once the fire starts burning, the damp and the dry will burn together.
persian.category: be careful who you choose to be your friends.

persian.text: One hand has no sound.
persian.category: reference to the effectiveness of cooperation among people, to do good or evil.

persian.text: One will take someone to the spring and bring them back thirsty.
She tells the sun, "Don’t rise. I’ve come out!"
Someone cut before they measured!
Taking rye to (the city of) Kerman.
persian.category: about doing something that is a waste of time.

persian.text: The mouse couldn’t fit through the hole, and then it tied a broom to its tail.
persian.category: refers to people who take on more responsibilities than they can handle.

persian.text: They count the chickens at the end of autumn.
persian.category: don’t act as if you have something until you really do.

persian.text: They tried to fix the eyebrow and ended up blinding the eye, too.
persian.category: instead of fixing the problem, they made it worse.

persian.text: Walls have mice; mice have ears.
persian.category: be careful. someone might be listening!

persian.text: Water finds the pothole.
persian.category: people with similar characteristics find each other.

persian.text: We’re alive for the lack of a shroud. – [i.e.,
persian.description: because we cannot afford a funeral
persian.category: because we cannot afford a funeral

persian.text: Whatever you sow, you reap.
persian.category: it is often so, but not always. lots of people inherit what others have sown, for one thing.

persian.text: When the water goes uphill, the frog sings Abu Ata.
persian.category: its same old song as before.

persian.text: When you pick up the stick, the stealing cat gets alert.
persian.category: guilty people are always on guard, looking over their shoulder.

persian.text: With a single flower, there won’t be spring.
persian.category: one needs more than one indication to draw conclusions.

persian.text: Yoke not a camel and a cat together.
"That smells bad," said the cat about meat that it cannot reach.
A bad event had a good sequel.
A bad wound heals, but a bad word doesn’t.
A bee is always behind the flower.
A beggar will always be a beggar even if they give him the whole world as a gift.
A blind man who sees is better than a sighted man who is blind.
A broken hand works, but not a broken heart.
A broken sleeve holdeth the arm back.
A camel does not drink with a spoon.
A camel that wants fodder stretches out its neck.
A child is a bridge to heaven.
A coquettish woman is like a shadow — as you chase her she runs away, and if you run away, she chases after you.
A coquettish woman is like a shadow — as you chase her she runs away, and if you run away, she chases after you.
A crazy person enjoys meeting another one.
A dog by your side is better than a brother miles away.
A drop is ocean only when it is in the ocean.
A drop of rain makes no impression on a hard stone.
A drowning man is not bothered by rain.
A ewer and a hose do the same thing, but their real values show when they are pawned.
A flower is beautiful from all sides.
A fool and his money are soon parted.
A fool’s excuse is bigger than his mistake.
A friend is like a poem.
A gentle hand may lead even an elephant by a single hair.
A good appetite needs no sauce.
A good year is apparent from the spring.
A good year is evident in its Spring.
A hasty man does things twice
A hungry man dreams of sangak bread.
A hungry person dreams of sangak bread.
A lazy sheep thinks its wool heavy.
A leopard cannot change its spots. Putting lipstick on a pig doesn’t make it a lady.
A liar is forgetful.
A liar should have a good memory.
A man can pose as a wise when searching for wisdom, but if he believes to have find it, is a fool.
A man without a child is a king without sorrows.
A man without passion is no son of Adam.
A man’s servant can live for a hundred years; the slave of a woman dies in six months.
A mirror does not reflect a broken heart.
A mountain never meets a mountain, but a man meets a man.
A person is trying to benefit from being close to opposing parties.
A quality statement often gets no answer.
A renter becomes a comfortable dweller.
A rolling stone gathers no moss.
persian.description: Only a stone that is in the same place for a long time will have moss growing on it. A stone on the move will remain bare. The same is true with people.

persian.text: A sharp tongue will cut off its own head.
A single flower makes not Spring.
A single rose does not mean that it is spring.
A slap in the face now is better than promised candy later.
A sluggard claims the wisdom of forty viziers.
A snake can change its skin but not its disposition.
A stone thrown at the right time is better than a stone thrown at the wrong time.
A stone thrown at the right time is better than gold given at the wrong time.
A sword in the hands of a drunken slave is less dangerous than science in the hands of the immoral.
A sword in the hands of a drunken slave is less dangerous than science in the hands of the unscrupulous.
A tear at the right moment is better than a misplaced smile.
A thief is a king until he is caught.
A thief knows a thief as a wolf knows a wolf.
A timely tear is better than a misplaced smile.
A visitor comes with ten blessings, eats one, and leaves nine.
A wise enemy is better than a foolish friend.
A wise man can laugh at his jokes.
A wolf’s repentance died a long time ago.
Acquaintance without patience is like a candle with no light.
All fur coat and no knickers
All that glitters is not gold.
All that is round is not walnut.
All work is as seed sown; it grows and spreads, and sows itself anew.
Amongst the genus of Jasminum, a single jasmine does not stand out.
An alive person needs life.
An arrow can be pulled out of a wound, but a hurtful word stays forever in your heart.
An ass is the most pleasing to another ass.
An egg thief becomes a camel thief.
An event is so improbable that its occurrence is akin to cacophony sounding mellifluous.
An honest broker shares in people’s wealth.
An infidel believes of everybody being of his own faith.
An ungrateful son is a wart on his father’s nose – he leaves it, it’s ugly, he removes it, it hurts.
Appearances can be deceptive.
Applied when a person mentions the problems of another without seeing his own bigger problems.
Arabic is a language, Persian is a delicacy and Turkish is an art.
As long as the clouds dolt weep, the pasture cannot laugh.
As long as you are standing, give a hand to those who have fallen.
As soon as a man gets new trousers, he thinks about a new wife.
As the best wine makes the sharpest vinegar, the truest lover may turn into the worst enemy.
As the wise man looks for a bridge the fool crosses the river.
Asked for an eye-witness, the fox offered his tail.
Aspiration is not a defect for youngsters.
Bake the bread while the oven is hot.
Bam’s eggplant doesn’t have a defect.
Be a lion at home and a fox abroad.
Be careful. People could be listening.
Be in league with the headman; pillage the village.
Be it a bread given to the beggar, be it one taken from him.
Be kind to the debtor and he becomes the creditor.
Be not all sugar, or the world will swallow you up; be not all wormwood, or the world will spit you out.
Beggars can’t be choosers.
persian.description: If someone gives you free things or offers to help you do something, you can’t ask for a different color or choose the perfect time in your schedule. When you receive free help or goods, you should accept what you’re offered—you can’t be picky (a “chooser”) because you’re not paying!

persian.text: Being tricky (untruthful) won’t get you to your goal.
Better safe than sorry.
Between two cooks, the soup becomes either salty or bland.
Beware a rickety wall, a savage dog, and a quarrelsome person.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Blood cannot be washed out with blood.
Bravery without foresight is like a blind horse.
Bribery makes both parties happy.
Bugbear took it all.
Bugbear took that pacifier.
Buy cheap, buy a heap.
By a sweet tongue and kindness, you can drag an elephant with a hair.
Children are the bridge to heaven.
Claim to virginity, after seven moppets!
Closing the barn door after the horses get out.
Cloud, wind, moon, and sky are at work. And when you earn a piece of bread, do not eat it in ignorance.
Come what may.
Comfortable is he who doesn’t have a donkey — Doesn’t know of its straw and barley.
Comfortable is he who doesn’t have a donkey — He who doesn’t know of its straw and barley.
Contrarily, they call the Negro Camphor.
Courteous men learn courtesy from the discourteous.
Courtesy is cumbersome to them that ken it not.
Courtesy on just one side can never last long.
Courtesy on one side can never last long.
Credit is better than wealth.
Crooked load will not get to the destination.
Curiosity is the key to knowledge.
Death is a camel that lies down at every door.
Death is a camel that lies down at everyone’s door.
Debts are like women, once you have them you can’t get rid of them.
Did you see the camel? No you did not!
Do a good thing and throw it in the river. God will reward you in the desert.
Do little things now; and big things will come to you.
Do little things now; so shall big things come to thee by and by asking to be done.
Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?
Do men gather grapes of thorns?
Do not be critical of what has been given to you for free.
Do not choose for anyone what you do not choose for yourself.
Do not cut down the tree that gives you shade.
Do not let the cat watch over the bacon.
Do not use words that are too big for your mouth.
Do well the little things now; so shall great things come to thee by and by asking to be done.
Don’t just take love—experience it.
Don’t be afraid of he who raises a hue and cry; be afraid of he who holds his head down.
Don’t be afraid of he who’s loud and noisy, be afraid of he who’s head is down.
Don’t bite the hand that feeds you.
persian.description: This proverb warns against acting mean to those who provide for you or who do nice things for you. If you were to bite the hand that gave you food, that hand probably won’t come back to feed you again. Then what would you eat? So you should be kind and thankful to those who care for you.

persian.text: Don’t borrow from a baby-boomer, if you borrow, don’t spend it.
Don’t borrow from a parvenu; if you do, don’t spend it.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
persian.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

persian.text: Don’t despise pepper because it is so small; eat, and see how pungent it is.
Don’t have too many irons in the fire.
Don’t judge a book by its cover
persian.description: Things are not always what they seem. This proverb teaches you not to make judgments about other people because of how they look or dress. A book with a boring or plain cover could be amazing. The same is true with people. A person might look like an athlete or fool, but there is probably a lot more to them than clothes suggest.

persian.text: Don’t just take love, experience it.
Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth.
Don’t rock the boat. Don’t make waves.
Doubt is the key to knowledge.
Doubt makes the mountain which faith can move.
Doubtful the die, and dire the cast.
Draw not thy bow before thy arrow be fixed.
Drawn wells have sweetest water.
Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.
Easy come, easy go.
persian.description: Money, fame, love or anything that happens easily can be lost just as quickly. If you get a lot of money or suddenly become famous, you could lose that money or fame very quickly—since you didn’t work hard to earn it.

persian.text: Eat bread and leek for one year, eat bread and butter for a hundred years.
Eat drink and make merry, for tomorrow you might die
Eating and sleeping is my profession, God Almighty is my protection.
Either God, or date
Empty vessels make the most noise. Barking dogs seldom bite.
Epigrams might succeed where epics fail.
Epigrams succeed where epics fail.
Even a hair off the bear is serendipitous.
Even if she had seven blind daughters, she’d marry them off in an hour.
Every fault that a Sultan pleases can be a quality.
Every man goes down to his death bearing in his hands only that which he has given away.
Every man is the architect of his own fortune.
Every man is the king of his own beard.
Every man is the smith of his own fortune.
Every rock strikes the feet of the poor.
Every tear has a smile behind it.
Every time something turns out missing.
Every tree is known by its fruit.
Everyone thinks his own spit tastes good.
Excessive praise is like an insult.
Expect trust from a dog but not from a woman.
Experience is a comb which nature gives to men when they are bald.
Fear those who do not fear God.
Fine words butter no parsnips.
Fire is a good servant but a bad master.
First dig a well, then steal the minaret.
First goblet and then drunkenness.
First goblet is still full, but you are sodden (or drunk).
First prove your brotherhood, then claim inheritance.
Five fingers are brothers, not equals.
Flies will easily fly into the honey — their problem is how to get out.
Flies will never leave the shop of a sweetmaker.
For a single guest, the host can a slaughter a cow.
For an ant to have wings would be his undoing.
For crystal rain falls from black clouds.
For his master the dog is a lion.
Forgiveness hides a pleasure that you can’t get back from revenge.
Four walls make a man free.
Friendship with a fool may turn into the hug of a bear.
From afar he takes the heart, from nearby the gall-bladder.
From sudden desire of halim he fell in the pot.
From this column to that column may be a relief.
From truth to falsehood there’s a four-finger distance.
From you motion, from God blessing.
From you, action, from God, benediction.
Get along with the village headman, plunder the village.
Give him an inch and he’ll take a mile.
Give nine, save ten.
Giving advice to the ignorant is like the rain falling on muddy ground.
Go and wake up your luck.
Go as far as you can see, and when you get there you’ll see further.
Go further and fare worse.
Go slowly and come slowly so that the cat won’t gore you.
God gives to us according to the measure of our hearts.
God provides, but He needs a nudge.
Goes in one ear comes out the other.
Gold bears more gold.
Good deeds return to the house of their author.
Good grape becomes fox’s possession.
Good poets are like angels of Heaven.
Goods have value only to those who desire them.
Great boast, small roast.
Great needs grow from great possessions.
Great talkers are little doers.
Habits are first cobwebs, then cables.
Had the crow been a surgeon, it would have stitched its own rear.
He doesn’t see any water; otherwise, he is a skilled swimmer.
He doesn’t see water, otherwise he is a skilled swimmer.
He eats sheep-tail with the wold, and cries with the shepherd.
He escaped the thief, and fell in fortune-teller’s trap.
He gives a party with bath-water.
He gives from caliph’s bag.
He gives him roast meat and beats him with the spit.
He has dealt with so many scoundrels that he himself has become the chief rogue.
He has eaten so many snakes that he has become a viper.
He has fallen off the donkey, but has found a date.
He has lost the horse, but is looking for the horseshoe.
He is still alive because he cannot afford a funeral.
He is still wet behind the ears.
He keeps her/his face red with slaps.
He makes the water muddy to fish.
He never tells the truth.
He pushes it away with the hand, but pulls it forward with the foot.
He pushes it back with his hand and pulls it in with his feet.
He runs with the hare and hunst with the hound.
He takes from one ear, and lets it out from the other ear.
He that sows shall also reap.
he tried to pluck under her/his eyebrow, but blinded the eye.
He wants the God and the date both.
He wants to have his cake and eat it too.
He wants to have it both ways.
He wants to let it go and still have it.
He who doesn’t go to war roars like a lion.
He who eats alone is Satan’s brother.
He who has a clean account, what fear of calculation does he have?
He who has been bitten by a snake fears a piece of string.
He who has had his nose in the air bites the dust in the end.
He who has only one enemy, meets him everywhere.
He who is honest at finance, what fear of audit will he have?

He who knows not, and knows not that he knows not, is a fool, shun him; He who knows not, and knows that he knows not, is a child, teach him. He who knows, and knows not that he knows, is asleep, wake him. He who knows, and knows that he knows, is wise, follow him.
He who puts on lordly airs winds up hauling hay.
He who sits waiting for his neighbor will go to bed hungry.
He who want a rose must respect the thorn.
He who wants content can’t find an easy chair.
He who wants the rose must respect the thorn.
He whose heart is aroused by love will never die.
He would even hang himself, provided that the rope is free.
He wouldn’t sleep where there is running water.
He, who has only one enemy, meets him everywhere.
He/she who blows into fire will have sparkles in his/her eyes.
Heaven is at the feet of mothers.
Hey sloth, don’t go into the shade, the shade would eventually come to you.
His mouth still smells of his mother’s milk.
His options are so limited that he has to settle for the worst pinchbeck.
History is a mirror of the past, and a lesson for the present.
Hitch a horse and an ass to the same post; if they don’t smell the same, they’ll behave the same.
Human beings need meaningful lives.
I attempted to be benevolent, but I got burnt.
I can only get better if I have good friends.
I cried because I had no shoes until I met a man who had no feet.
I eat what others have planted and I plant what others want to eat.
I gave so much advice that hair grew on my tongue.
I have no right to rejoice at the death of my enemy when I do not have eternal life myself.
I know entirely what kind of person you are.
I murmured because I had no shoes, until I met a man who had no feet.
I poured our own flour and hung our hair-sieve.
I took care of my own business.
I took the abandoned boy to be my son, but he became my husband.
I tried to do charity, I burned.
I used to complain because I had no shoes until I met a man who had no feet.
I used to complain because I had no shoes until I met a man who was dead.
I used to feel sorry for myself because I had no shoes until I met a man who was dead.
I was trying to help out, but I got in trouble myself.
I wept because I had no shoes, until I saw a man who had no feet.
I would have been for seven years.
If a fool borrows a book cut off his hand; but cut off both hands of the fool who brings it back.
If a man would live in peace, he should be blind, deaf, and dumb.
If Akbar doesn’t give, Akbar’s God gives.
If Ali is the camel-driver, he knows where to rest his camel.
If children’s prayer had any effect, there wouldn’t be a single teacher alive.
If everybody said bread and cheese, you put your head down and die.
If everyone said bread and cheese, you put your head down and desist.
If fortune turns against you, even jelly breaks your tooth.
If God wills, even males become fertile.
If he hadn’t seen his father, he would have claimed kingship.
If he has seven blind daughters, he will marry them in an hour.
If he hasn’t seen her/his father, he would claim to be a king.
If he says yogurt is white, I’ll say it’s black.
If he was any good, his name would be Kheirollah.
If he were a do-gooder, they’d call him Saint Do-Gooder.
If I haven’t eaten wheat-bread, I’ve seen it in people’s hands.
If it doesn’t have water for me, instead it has bread for you.
If my aunt had a beard, this man would be my uncle.
If one has to jump a stream and knows how wide it is, he will not jump. If he does not know how wide it is, he will jump, and six times out of ten he will make it.
If regret was a horn, one’s horn would reach the sky.
If regret was a horn, the fellow’s horn would reach the sky.
If something is needed at home, its donation is wrong
If the beginning is good, the end must be perfect.
If the lantern is needed at home, donating it to the mosque is haram (forbidden).
If the Lor doesn’t go to bazaar, everything will rot.
If the Sultan demands five eggs, let his soldiers roast a thousand chickens.
If the teacher be corrupt, the world will be corrupt.
If there are two cooks in one house, the soup is either too salty or too cold.
If they had planted "if," a tree would have grown in its place.
If we haven’t eaten wheat bread, we’ve seen it in people’s hands.
If wishes were horses, beggars would ride.
If you are a surgeon, set your own bones.
If you be a cock, crow; if a hen, lay eggs.
If you can give me no ointment for my wound, can you help me by not rubbing salt in?
If you do not like your image in the mirror, do not break the mirror. Break yours.
If you don’t crack the shell, you can’t eat the nut.
If you enter the city of the blind, cover your eyes.
If you exercise patience, you may make a sweet-meat out of the sour grape.
If you fall into a pit, Providence is under no obligation to come and look for you.
If you go on foot, you’ll wear out your shoes; if you go on head, you’ll wear out your hat.
If you know how to lullaby, why can’t you put yourself to sleep?
If you know lullaby, why can’t you sleep?
If you really have to sin, then choose a sin that you enjoy.
If you talk Ali to him, don’t mention Omar.
If you tell the truth too early, you are laughed at – too late and you are stoned.
If you walk with your feet your shoe will get worn, if you walk with your head, your hat.
If you work hard and live uncomfortably today, it’ll pay off in the future.
If you’re a reed-player, why did your father die of typhoid fever?
If you’re a shoveler, shovel your garden first.
In at one ear and out at the other.
In one ear, out the other.
In shaping one’s own fortune one should not rely on the help of others, as they are also concerned mainly about their own matters.
In the ants’ house the dew is a flood.
In the hotel of decisions the guests sleep well.
In the hour of adversity be not without hope For crystal rain falls from black clouds.
In the hour of adversity be not without hope.
In the hour of adversity do not give up hope for crystal rainfalls from black clouds.
In this world generous people have no money and those with money are not generous.
In winter a fire is better than a muscat blossom.
In your neighbors’ soup there is always one fatty morsel.
Injustice all around is justice!
It is a real compliment that comes from an enemy.
It is a wise man who can laugh at his own jokes.
It is better to be careful and to not risk making a big mistake.
It is better to be in chains with friends, than to be in a garden with strangers.
It is better to die in honor than to live in disgrace.
It is not from the love of God that the cat catches mice.
It is nothing for one to know something unless another knows you know it.
It is so unlikely to obtain anything from this person that even a smidgen is a win.
It is the mountains that do not move to help one another; but one man surely comes to the help of another.
It is the same to him who wears a shoe, as if the whole earth were covered with leather.
It is too late for you, let God give your children some intelligence.
It is too late for you, let God give your children some intelligence.
It seems like folly to give comfits to a cow – It can be fun anyway.
It takes ten pounds of common sense to carry one pound of learning.
It takes two days to learn everything about a man; to know animals you will need more time.
It’s better to flee and stay alive than to die and become a hero.
It’s better to fly and stay alive than to die a hero.
It’s from us that is on us.
It’s from us, what’s upon us.
It’s no use throwing good money after bad.
It’s not possible to go to sky by a ladder.
I’ve seen your top, I’ve seen your bottom also.
Keep your own counsel. Watch your back.
Kettledrum’s sound is nice when heard from afar.
Laugh and the world laughs with you.
Learn good manners from those who don’t have them.
Left from there, driven from here.
Let the manager manage.
Let the person in responsibility take care of the matter, as is the most able.
Life is like perpetual drunkenness, the pleasure passes but the headache remains.
Like a cow with a blaze.
Like fault, like punishment.
Listening to good advice is the way to wealth.
Little by little the cotton thread becomes a turban.
Little by little the wool becomes a carpet.
Look at the colander telling the pierced serving spoon, "You have three holes."
Look at the strainer that tells the skimmer: You have three holes.
Look in the sky to find the moon, not in the pond.
Luck is infatuated with the efficient.
Lucky are those who don’t have too many responsibilities.
Lying in the gutter, looking at the stars.
Make bread while the oven is hot.
Many a little makes a Mickle.
Marriage is an uncut watermelon.
Maturity comes from impressions for a long time.
Maturity comes from wisdom, not in the passing of years.
May God strike the rich man blind by his own gold.
Might as well be hanged for a sheep as a lamb. In for a penny, in for a pound.
Mo’ Money, Mo’ Problems.
Mountains don’t meet, but people do.
Much coin, much care.
My good deed was blamed or punished.
Necessity can change a lion into a fox.
Necessity turns lion into fox.
Never open a door that you can’t lock again.
No benefit has come from this individual.
No good comes of this person.
No good deed goes unpunished.
No lamp burns till morning.
Nobody sees a miracle from this shrine.
Not everyone who sings a lullaby stays awake.
Nothing is cheap for no reason.
Nothing is disturbed. No waves are made.
Of everything else the newest; of friends, the oldest.
Often the best way of giving oneself what one lacks is to take from oneself what one has.
Oh God: Three mishaps at the same time; a limping donkey, an ugly wife, and a creditor.
Oh peach, get into (my) throat.
Once a friend, always a friend.
Once I had the strength but no wisdom; now I have the wisdom but no strength.
One crow and forty crows.
One cuts and one sews.
One doesn’t pay attention to the given advice.
One finds money on Wednesday and one loses it.
One finger cannot lift a pebble.
One full stomach is better than hundred half-full stomachs.
One good father can do more than 100 schoolmasters.
One hurts you in a way you don’t register it.
One idiot throws a stone in the well, and it takes a hundred wise men to (try to) get it out.
One is very skillful.
One pound of learning could require an army of common sense to apply it.
One pound of learning might have required many thousand persons of common sense to acquire it.
One pound of learning requires ten pounds of common sense to apply it.
One scabby goat infects the flock.
One sin is too much, a hundred prayers are not enough.
One sip of wine is an antidote against death, cupfuls poison life.
One spark is enough to burn a hundred worlds.
One who is poor at finance pays twice.
One who’s been bitten by a snake is afraid of a black-and-white rope.
One who’s innocent is not afraid of investigation.
One’s children are almond hulls; one’s grandchildren are almond nuts.
One’s very regretful.
Only a heart can find the way to another heart.
Oosta Alam, take this one into account.
Our means are exiguous. (We continue to live, because we couldn’t afford the funeral cost, if we were to die.)
Our real grave is not in the ground but in men’s hearts.
Out of desperation, he calls donkey dame.
Out of extreme desire for achieving something, he got in trouble.
Out of the frying pan into the fire.
Play, play, with the beard of the father also play?
Pot calling the kettle black.
Poured clear water on hither hands.
Practice makes perfect.
persian.description: It would be amazing if the first time you picked up a guitar you could play it like a rock star. Or if the first time you got in a car, you could drive like a professional. Or if you could speak English perfectly after one lesson. Everything is difficult when you are a beginner. But if you stick with it, if you keep practicing, you can master anything.

persian.text: Practice what you preach.
persian.description: If you say that everyone needs to arrive on time, make sure that you also arrive on time.

persian.text: Praise a fair day at night.
Pride comes before a fall
Putting the cart before the horse.
Putting the cart before the horse.
Raise the one you’ve delivered.
Raise what you’ve given birth to.
Seek knowledge from the cradle to the grave.
Seek truth in meditation, not in moldy books. Look in the sky to find the moon, not in the pond.
Seven sets of ewers and washbowls, but no dinner or lunch.
Seven sets of ewers, but no dinner nor lunch.
Share and share alike.
She doles out of Caliph’s purse.
She has become hale. Her appearance has improved.
She is a mother to everyone, but a stepmother to us.
She is in the pink.
Silence betokens consent.
Silence is the sign of agreement.
So down-and-out, so high-and-mighty!
So many donkeys around, yet we have to hoof it.
Solved riddles look easy.
Some good poets are like angels of Heaven.
Someone is being generous at someone else’s expense.
Sometimes the body becomes healthy by being very sick.
Speak in the frame of reference of your audience.
Spectators see better than actors.
Spilled water cannot be gathered again.
Spring doesn’t come with just a single flower.
Spring won’t come from one flower.
Stand so much until grass grows under your foot.
Step by step one ascends the stairs.
Stretch your foot to the length of your blanket.
Take care lest your tongue should cut off your head.
Take from the hungry, give it to the full/satisfied.
Take it from the famished and give it to the nourished.
Take to your aunt what you’ve brought to me.
Taking the first step with the good thought, the second with the good word, and the third with the good deed, I enter paradise.
Taste it first before you say it’s saltless.
Tell a lazy man to do something. Listen to philosophy!
Tell me who your friends are, and I will tell you who you are!
That smells bad, said the cat about meat that it cannot reach.
The arrow that has left the bow never returns.
The best memory is that which forgets nothing, but injuries. Write kindness in marble and write injuries in the dust.
The best mode of instruction is to practise what we preach.
The best of friends must part.
The best of men are but men at best.
The big drum only sounds well from a distance.
The bigger a man’s head, the worse his headache.
The blind man is laughing at the bald head.
The branch that bears the most fruit bends itself thankfully towards the ground.
The bride who wears four petticoats has a lot to hide.
The cripple will always find a stone to kick.
The devil looks after his own.
The diamond fallen into the dunghill is not the less precious for it.
The doctor must heal his own bald head.
The dog is a lion in his own house.
The drowning man is not troubled by rain.
The earth is a host who kills his guests.
The elephant dreams of one thing, and the elephant driver dreams of another.
The ewer is cheaper than its solder.
The eyes can do a thousand things that the fingers can’t.
The fireside is the tulip bed of a winter day.
The fool’s excuse is bigger than the mistake he made.
The fox uses his tale as a witness.
The guard’s sleep is the lamplight of the thief.
The halfwit spoke, and the brainless believed.
The hand that gives is also the one that receives.
The horse is Turkmen, it eats from both the nose-bag and the manger.
The issue is muddled at the core.
The joy of finding something is often worth more than what is found.
The lack of gold only a headache.
The larger a man’s roof, the more snow it collects.
The leek resembles its seed and little Hassan takes after his father.
The legs of those who require proofs of God’s existence are made of wood.
The loveliest of faces are to be seen by moonlight, when one sees half with the eye and half with the fancy.
The lover who gives you her body but not her heart is generous with thornless roses.
The main thing is to be pretty and fair; bald spots are covered by the hair.
The mediator in a fight gets all the blows.
The monkey could not dance and blamed it on the floor as being crooked.
The mud that you throw will fall on your own head.
The needle makes clothes but stays naked.
The neighbor’s hen is a goose to a neighbor.
The night hides a world, but reveals a universe.
The ostrich was asked to carry a load, it said. I’m a bird. It was asked to fly, it said, I’m a camel.
The person is so destitute that his fortune will not change with a penny given or taken.
The person who tells the truth is always at ease.
The person who wants a rose must respect the thorn.
The pitcher is cheaper than its solder.
the place is wet and the child is missing.
The pleasure of finding something is worth more than what you find.
The pot calling the kettle black.
The public improves the speaker’s speech.
The reticent can be more dangerous than the boisterous.
The rich are subjugated by their greed for more riches.
The rich get richer, the poor get poorer.
The richer they are, the needier they are.
The shoemaker’s shoes have no heels.
The sky is of the same color wherever you go.
The sky is the same color wherever you go.
The solution is under our nose, yet we’re searching far and wide for it.
The strictness of the teacher is better to bear than the prejudice of the father.
The tears of the roasting meat kindle the fire even more.
The tongue of men is the whip of God.
The virtuous will be praised but not envied.
The walls have mice, the mice have ears.
The water doesn’t move.
The water has passed his head.
The way a house is decorated will tell much about its owner.
The wise man sits on the hole in his carpet.
The wise man who does not put his knowledge into practice is like a bee that gives no honey.
The world is a rose: smell it and pass it on to your friends.
The world is like an old building on the banks of a stream – it carries away piece by piece; in vain you stop it with a handful of earth.
There are four things every person has more of than they know . . .
There are four things every person has more of than they know; sins, debt, years, and foes.
There are four things in this life of which we have more than we think: faults, debts, years and enemies.
